subject: statistics
title: Interval Estimation for Differences
contentHtml:
When comparing two means or proportions, we often want to know if there's a significant difference between them. Interval estimation provides a range of values within which the true difference lies.

This concept is crucial in many fields, including machine learning and artificial intelligence, where understanding the differences between models or algorithms can be vital.

intuition: Interval estimation for differences helps us quantify the uncertainty in our estimates, making it easier to make informed decisions.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the performance of two machine learning models
commonMistakes: Failing to account for the variability in the data
Using a fixed margin of error instead of a confidence interval

subject: statistics
title: Confidence Intervals for Differences
contentHtml:
When comparing two means or proportions, we often want to know if the difference is statistically significant. This is where confidence intervals (CIs) come in â€“ they provide a range of values within which the true difference lies.

Intuitively, think of it like trying to estimate the distance between two cities on a map. You can't get an exact measurement, but you can construct a region that's likely to contain the true value.
name: CI for differences
intuition: Think of it like a 'margin of error' for the difference between two means or proportions.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, CIs can be used to quantify the uncertainty in model predictions.

subject: statistics
title: Interval Estimation for Differences: Two Means and Proportions
contentHtml:
When comparing two means or proportions, interval estimation is a powerful tool to quantify the uncertainty in our estimates.

Imagine you're testing the effectiveness of a new marketing campaign by comparing the mean response rate between two groups. You want to know not only if there's a difference but also how confident you can be in that difference.
name: Two-sample CI for means
variants: [ {"latex": "\\[CI = p_1 - p_2 \pm z_{\\alpha/2} \\sqrt{\\frac{p_1(1-p_1)}{n_1} + \\frac{p_2(1-p_2)}{n_2}}\\]", "description": "Two-sample CI for proportions"} ] },
intuition: Interval estimation provides a range of plausible values for the difference, accounting for sampling variability. This helps you make informed decisions and avoid false positives or negatives.
commonMistakes: Failing to account for the uncertainty in the estimate
Not considering the sample size when interpreting the CI
realWorldApplications: Comparing the effectiveness of different marketing campaigns
Evaluating the impact of a new treatment on patient outcomes
